BusinessItemDetail.ItemText: Followed by

DayItem.Title: Notice of Motion for An Unopposed Return
NOTICE OF MOTION FOR AN UNOPPOSED RETURN

BusinessItemDetail.ItemText: That an Humble Address be presented to His Majesty, That he will be graciously pleased to give directions that there be laid before this House a Return of the Report from the Right Honourable Sir Alan Moses, Chairman of the Spoliation Advisory Panel, dated 18 March 2024, in respect of three oil sketches by Sir Peter Paul Rubens now in the possession of the Courtauld Institute of Art, London.

DayItem.Title: Questions to the Secretary of State for Work and Pensions
Topical Questions to the Secretary of State for Work and Pensions
PROCEEDINGS ON THE SUPPLY AND APPROPRIATION (ANTICIPATION AND ADJUSTMENTS) BILL

BusinessItemDetail.Notes:
The Questions for Second and Third Reading of the Supply and Appropriation (Anticipation and Adjustments) Bill must be put without debate and may be decided after 10.00pm (Standing Order No. 56).

This Bill is expected to be certified as a Money Bill.

DayItem.Title: SAFETY OF RWANDA (ASYLUM AND IMMIGRATION) BILL: PROGRAMME (No. 2)

BusinessItemDetail.ItemText: That the following provisions shall apply to the Safety of Rwanda (Asylum and Immigration) Bill for the purpose of supplementing the Order of 12 December 2023 (Safety of Rwanda (Asylum and Immigration) Bill: Programme): Consideration of Lords Amendments (1) Proceedings on consideration of Lords Amendments shall (so far as not previously concluded) be brought to a conclusion at 8.00pm at today’s sitting. Subsequent stages (2) Any further Message from the Lords may be considered forthwith without any Question being put. (3) Proceedings on the first of any further Messages from the Lords shall (so far as not previously concluded) be brought to a conclusion two hours after their commencement. (4) Proceedings on any subsequent Message from the Lords shall (so far as not previously concluded) be brought to a conclusion one hour after their commencement.

DayItem.Title: SAFETY OF RWANDA (ASYLUM AND IMMIGRATION) BILL: CONSIDERATION OF LORDS AMENDMENTS

BusinessItemDetail.Notes: For motions relating to the Lords Amendments, see separate paper (also available on the documents webpage for the Bill). None of the Lords  Amendments engages financial privilege.
BusinessItemDetail.Duration: Until 8.00pm (If the Safety of Rwanda (Asylum and Immigration) Bill: Programme (No. 2) motion is agreed to)

BusinessItemDetail.Notes: If this item is opposed after 10.00pm, the division will be deferred.
BusinessItemDetail.ItemText: That the draft Combined Authorities (Overview and Scrutiny Committees, Access to Information and Audit Committees) (Amendment) Regulations 2024, which were laid before this House on 19 February, be approved.

BusinessItemDetail.Notes: If this item is opposed after 10.00pm, the division will be deferred.

BusinessItemDetail.Notes: If this item is opposed after 10.00pm, the division will be deferred.

BusinessItemDetail.Notes: If this item is opposed after 10.00pm, the division will be deferred.

BusinessItemDetail.Notes: If this item is opposed after 10.00pm, the division will be deferred.

BusinessItemDetail.Notes: If this item is opposed after 10.00pm, the division will be deferred.
BusinessItemDetail.ItemText: That the draft Electricity Capacity (Supplier Payment etc.) (Amendment and Excluded Electricity) Regulations 2024, which were laid before this House on 22 January, be approved.

BusinessItemDetail.Notes: If this item is opposed after 10.00pm, the division will be deferred.
BusinessItemDetail.ItemText: That the draft Energy-Intensive Industry Electricity Support Payments and Levy Regulations 2024, which were laid before this House on 22 January, be approved.

BusinessItemDetail.Notes: If this item is opposed after 10.00pm, the division will be deferred.
BusinessItemDetail.ItemText: That the draft Economic Crime and Corporate Transparency Act 2023 (Consequential, Supplementary and Incidental Provisions) Regulations 2024, which were laid before this House on 1 February, be approved.

BusinessItemDetail.Notes: If this item is opposed after 10.00pm, the division will be deferred.
BusinessItemDetail.ItemText: That the draft Economic Crime and Corporate Transparency Act 2023 (Financial Penalty) Regulations 2024, which were laid before this House on 19 February, be approved.

BusinessItemDetail.Notes: If this item is opposed after 10.00pm, the division will be deferred.
BusinessItemDetail.ItemText: That the Russia (Sanctions) (EU Exit) (Amendment) Regulations 2024 (SI, 2024, No. 218), dated 26 February, a copy of which was laid before this House on 28 February, be approved.

BusinessItemDetail.SponsorNotes: On behalf of the Committee of Selection
BusinessItemDetail.ItemText: That Sir Jeremy Quin be discharged from the Committee of Public Accounts and Matt Warman be added.

DayItem.Title: Recommendations of the Infected Blood Inquiry

BusinessItemDetail.Duration: Until 10.30pm or for half an hour (whichever is later)

DayItem.Title: Order of Business
DayItem.Notes: The sitting will last for up to three hours (Standing Order No. 10(1)).

DayItem.Title: That this House has considered e-petitions 630932 and 631529 relating to LGBT content in relationships education

BusinessItemDetail.Notes: The subject for this debate was determined by the Petitions Committee. The sitting will last for up to three hours. The sitting will be suspended and time added if divisions take place in the main Chamber (Standing Order No. 10(3)).
BusinessItemDetail.ItemText: That this House has considered e-petitions 630932 and 631529 relating to LGBT content in relationships education.

DayItem.Title: Publication of the Rural Report ‘Delivering Rural Opportunity’
British Council Annual Report and Accounts 2022-23
DHSC’s attendance at the tenth Conference of the Parties of the World Health Organization Framework Convention on Tobacco Control
Update on tackling intimidation in public life
Forthcoming End of Day Adjournment Debates

BusinessItemDetail.ItemText: Applications for 30-minute end of day adjournment debates should be made to the Table Office by 7.00pm or rise of the House, whichever is the earlier, on the Wednesdays listed below. Members can submit their application via MemberHub, from their own email account or in hard copy. Application forms are available on the Table Office page on ParliNet. The ballot takes place on the day following the deadline. Members who are successful will be contacted by the Speaker’s Office.

DayItem.Title: Monday 15 to Monday 22 April (deadline Wednesday 20 March 7.00pm or the rise of the House, whichever is earlier)
Tuesday 23 to Monday 29 April (deadline Wednesday 17 April 7.00pm or the rise of the House, whichever is earlier)
Tuesday 30 April to Thursday 2 May (deadline Wednesday 24 April 7.00pm or the rise of the House, whichever is earlier)
Tuesday 7 to Monday 13 May (deadline Wednesday 1 May 7.00pm or the rise of the House, whichever is earlier)

BusinessItemDetail.ItemText: The rota for answering Departments is listed below. Applications for 90, 60 and 30-minute debates should be made to the Table Office by 10.00pm or the rise of the House, whichever is the earlier, on the Mondays listed below. Members can submit their application via MemberHub, from their own email account or in hard copy. Application forms are available on the Table Office page on ParliNet. The ballot takes place on the day following the deadline. Members who are successful will be contacted by the Speaker's Office.

DayItem.Title: Tuesday 26 March (deadline Monday 18 March 10.00pm or the rise of the House, whichever is earlier)

BusinessItemDetail.ItemText:
The following Departments will answer: 

Business and Trade; Culture, Media and Sport; Energy Security and Net Zero; Home Office; Science, Innovation and Technology; Scotland; Transport; Treasury; Women and Equalities; Work and Pensions
